message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory workup suggest Cushing’s syndrome, and the absence of a pituitary adenoma suggests ectopic ACTH secretion. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is the best next step to confirm the source of excessive ACTH secretion. Repeat high dose dexamethasone suppression test is not necessary as the initial test was already responsive. Pituitary resection is not indicated as there is no evidence of a pituitary adenoma. Pulmonary nodule resection is also not indicated at this time as the nodule has been stable for 5 years and is unlikely to be the cause of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated cortisol levels and lack of response to low dose dexamethasone suppression test suggest Cushing's syndrome. The ACTH level suggests that it is due to a pituitary adenoma, but normal pituitary gland imaging suggests it may be an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling can help localize the source of ACTH secretion. Pulmonary nodule resection is not indicated as the nodule is asymptomatic and appears benign. Repeat high dose dexamethasone suppression test is not necessary as it has already been responsive. Pituitary resection can be considered if the source is confirmed to be a pituitary adenoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely suffering from Cushing’s syndrome due to the lab findings and imaging results. Since the patient’s high dose dexamethasone suppression test was responsive, it suggests that the excess cortisol production is not from the pituitary gland. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling can help localize the source of the excess cortisol production and guide further treatment. Pulmonary nodule resection is not necessary as the nodule has been present for 5 years and is likely benign. Pituitary resection is not indicated as the pituitary gland appears to be normal on imaging.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's lab results suggest Cushing's syndrome, and the imaging shows a calcified pulmonary nodule present for 5 years, which rules out primary hypercortisolism. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is used to determine the source of ACTH production and is the best next step in management. Pituitary resection is an option if there is a pituitary adenoma causing hypercortisolism, but the imaging results do not support this. Pulmonary nodule resection is not indicated unless the nodule is large enough to cause concern for cancer. A repeat high dose dexamethasone suppression test is not necessary since the patient has already responded to it.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of Cushing's syndrome, with elevated urinary and serum cortisol levels and a non-responsive low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test was responsive, which suggests an ACTH-dependent source of cortisol production, such as pituitary adenoma or ectopic production from another site. Imaging revealed a calcified pulmonary nodule but no pituitary or adrenal gland abnormalities. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is the next step in distinguishing whether the source of ACTH secretion is pituitary or ectopic.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lab results, including high serum cortisol level, and unresponsive low dose dexamethasone suppression test, suggest Cushing syndrome. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is used to differentiate between Cushing’s disease (an abnormality in the pituitary gland) and ectopic ACTH production (from a tumor outside the pituitary gland), and will guide further treatment. Pulmonary nodule resection is not necessary at this time as it is not the cause of Cushing syndrome, and pituitary resection is not indicated until the cause of Cushing syndrome is determined. Repeat high dose dexamethasone suppression test is unlikely to provide additional information in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s lab results suggest Cushing’s syndrome, and the lack of pituitary gland abnormalities suggests that the cause is an adrenal tumor. The best next step is to perform an inferior petrosal sinus sampling to confirm the diagnosis and localize the tumor. Repeat high dose dexamethasone suppression test is not necessary because the initial test was responsive. Pituitary resection is not indicated because the pituitary gland is normal. Pulmonary nodule resection is also not indicated because the nodule is not causing the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including persistent headache and elevated cortisol levels, suggest Cushing's syndrome. The unresponsive low dose dexamethasone suppression test and elevated ACTH level indicate a pituitary source of excess cortisol. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis and localize the source of excess ACTH production. The pulmonary nodule is not likely to be the cause of the patient's symptoms and does not require immediate treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with persistent headache that does not respond to typical migraine treatments, hypertension, and posterior cervical fat pads and central abdominal girth. These are all signs of Cushing's syndrome. The laboratory results support this diagnosis. The finding of a calcified pulmonary nodule may suggest a non-functioning adrenal adenoma as the source of cortisol production. The best next step in management is to perform an inferior petrosal sinus sampling to confirm the diagnosis and localize the source of cortisol production. Repeat high dose dexamethasone suppression test is not necessary as the initial test was already positive. Pituitary resection may be considered in the presence of a pituitary adenoma, which is not mentioned in this case. Pulmonary nodule resection is not necessary at this point as it is likely not causing the hypercortisolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory results suggest Cushing's Syndrome, and imaging revealed a pulmonary nodule. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling can help confirm ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome and identify the source of the ectopic ACTH secretion, which is likely the cause of the patient’s symptoms. Other options, such as repeating the dexamethasone suppression test, pituitary resection, or pulmonary nodule resection, may not address the underlying issue causing the patient’s symptoms.
